Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: AVATOL - Next Generation Phenomics for the Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
Darwin's theory of evolution explained that millions of species are related, and dealt biologists and paleontologists the enormous challenge of discovering the branching pattern of the Tree of Life. Work on this great challenge is producing a map of species-relatedness through Earth history, and answering questions such as "what is the closest relative of a species?" and "what species make important products?" To do this scientists draw on all heritable features, including genotypes (e.g., DNA) and phenotypes (e.g., anatomy). Studying phenotypes, however, has remained complicated and slow, because it has not been revolutionized by computer science and engineering innovations.

A team of biologists, computer scientists, and paleontologists will extend and adapt methods from computer vision, machine learning, crowd-sourcing and natural language processing to enable rapid and automated study of phenotypes for the Tree of Life on a vast scale. The three-year goal is to release large phenomic datasets built using new methods, and to provide the public and scientific community with tools for future work. Planned is the training of teachers and students (kindergarten - postdoctoral levels) and the engagement of "citizen scien-tists." Enormous phenomic datasets, many with images, will fill an important public interest in biodiversity and the fossil record.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A central problem in evolutionary biology is to reconstruct the tree of life by which species developed from other species over millions of years. To do this, scientists describe each species by a list of characters such as the number of teeth, the shape of leaves, or the presence of various DNA markers.  Each character is said to have a score (e.g., number of molars = 0, 4, or 8). Then these character scores can be analyzed by tree-building algorithms to find evolutionary trees that best explain the observations. The description of the many thousands of species (including extinct species known only through fossils) has been very slow. The goal of this project was to explore whether the emerging technologies of crowd-sourcing, computer vision, and natural language processing could accelerate this process. The research team developed software for crowd-sourcing, new algorithms for computer vision, and custom tools for natural language processing. These were evaluated in a series of experiments to see how accurately they could score characters across a range of species. The results were mixed. The crowd-sourcing study concluded that students in introductory biology classes could score characters accurately about 80% of the time. The computer vision study showed that bat skull teeth and plant leaves could be accurately scored, but different computer vision algorithms were required for each species group. Natural language processing methods were the most effective, but they also required significant engineering efforts for each major branch of the tree of life. The conclusion of the project is that all three technologies may be valuable for selected subparts of the tree of life. But each requires significant engineering and data preparation. They are therefore most cost-effectively applied to species groups containing many, similar species.
